Woodstock vet Joe Cocker dies at 70 of cancer

Singer Joe Cocker made a career of rendering soul/blues/R&B hits with his distinctly raspy voice.

Woodstock vet Joe Cocker dies at 70 of cancer

Brian Mansfield and Jerry Shriver, USA TODAY 4:35 p.m. EST December 22, 2014
Legendary singer Joe Cocker died Monday at age 70 after a long battle with lung cancer. Here, he performs at the 47th Montreux Jazz Festival in Montreux, Switzerland, on July 20, 2013. (Photo: Sandro Campardo, EPA)
Fullscreen
Cocker performs for a crowd of thousands at Woodstock Music and Art Fair in Bethel, N.Y., in August 1969. There, he memorably covered The Beatles' 'With a Little Help From My Friends' and Bob Dylan's 'Just Like a Woman.' (Photo: AP)
Fullscreen
Cocker sings 'Up Where We Belong' with Jennifer Warnes on the 'American Bandstand'-esque 'Solid Gold' in 1983. (Photo: Ron Wolfson, WireImage)
Fullscreen
Cocker and Warnes in 1983. They recorded duet 'UpWhere We Belong' for the 1982 drama 'An Officer and a Gentleman,' starring Richard Gere and Debra Winger. (Photo: Chris Walter, WireImage)
Fullscreen
Cocker and James Brown performing 'Go Crazy' together in January 1987. (Photo: Photo: File Photo, Detroit Free Press)
Fullscreen
Cocker performs at the 25th anniversary Woodstock '94 fest in Saugerties, N.Y., in August 1994. Along his old favorites, he covers Randy Newman's 'Unchain My Heart' and Ray Charles' 'Unchain My Heart.' (Photo: Eileen Blass, USA TODAY)
Fullscreen
A portrait of Cocker, shot in June 1998. (Photo: GNS Photo)
Fullscreen
Cocker poses in New York's Central Park in September 2000. He released 17th album 'No Ordinary World' that August. (Photo: Jim Cooper, AP)
Fullscreen
Cocker sings at the first day of the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival in New Orleans April 24, 2009. (Photo: Cheryl Gerber, AP)
Fullscreen
Cocker speaks after receiving the lifetime achievement award for music during the 48th Golden Camera award ceremony in Berlin, Germany on Feb. 12, 2013. Among his accolades, Cocker won one Grammy Award in his lifetime, for 'Up Where We Belong' with Warnes.  (Photo: Maurizio Gambarini, AP)
Fullscreen

    Last SlideNext Slide

    Joe Cocker on Feb. 2, 2013 in Berlin, Germany. The singer has died at 70.(Photo: Andreas Rentz, Getty Images)

    5498 CONNECT 264 TWEET 4 LINKEDIN 69 COMMENTEMAILMORE

    Singer Joe Cocker, who's huge raspy voice and even bigger stage presence thrilled rock audiences at Woodstock and beyond, has died. He was 70.

    Cocker died early Monday of lung cancer in Crawford, Colo., where he has lived for the past two decades with his wife Pam.

    Cocker was best known for a memorable Woodstock performance in 1969 where he covered The Beatles' With a Little Help From My Friends.

    The ballad You Are So Beautiful, with Cocker's voice cracking on the final emotional note, was a Top Ten hit in 1975. He reached the top of the charts in the 1980s with the duet Up Where We Belong, with Jennifer Warnes, that appeared in the movie An Officer and a Gentlemen. The song won them a 1983 Grammy Award for best vocal performance by a duo or group.

    USA TODAY

    Joe Cocker: A look back at the singer's career

    USA TODAY

    Passages 2014: Remembering souls who were inspirations

    Cocker also had hits with the Randy Newman song You Can Leave Your Hat On and When the Night Comes. Rolling Stone ranked him No. 97 on its list of 100 Greatest Singers.

    "Joe Cocker is a legendary artist of rock and blues history and yet he was one of the most humble men I've ever met,'' said Edgar Berger, chairman and CEO of Sony Music Entertainment, in a statement. "His iconic voice will forever be etched in our memories. Joe will live on in the hearts of millions of fans around the world."

    The Sheffield, England-born singer made his public debut at age 12, when his brother Victor invited him onstage to sing with his skiffle band. "My voice hadn't really broken, but I could sing all the Lonnie Donegan songs from the skiffle era," Cocker told USA TODAY's Brian Mansfield in 2012. "My brother and his band loved to hear me sing, because I could do them all in the same key."

    Cocker's early '60s band, Vance Arnold & The Avengers, initially missed out on the British Invasion, but he got a second chance during what he called "the Whiter Shade of Pale era." That 1967 Procol Harum hit reinvigorated the British pop scene and led directly to high-profile appearances by Cocker, including his Sunday afternoon set at Woodstock in 1969. Cocker sang several songs that day, including Delta Lady, Ray Charles' Let's Go Get Stoned and Bob Dylan's I Shall Be Released. But his version of The Beatles' With A Little Help From My Friends became a career-igniting performance.

    "We just had a good day," Cocker recalled. "We went on real early, and we got a good sound. It took a long time to connect with the audience, though."

    Cocker's version of the Beatles' song later regained popularity as the theme for the TV show The Wonder Years.

    In addition to his leathery, one-of-a-kind voice, Cocker also was known for his performance style, which included flailing arms and spasmodic body movements. That aspect became fodder for parody during a memorable 1976 appearance on Saturday Night Live, when John Belushi joined him onstage and impersonated him. At the time, Cocker was struggling with alcoholism and financial problems, but the appearance helped give his a career a boost.

    The singer frequently cited Ray Charles as his key influence and he got to perform You Are So Beautiful with the R&B great on a TV special in the '80s. "It was the most nerve-wracking experience I've ever gone through," Cocker said. Their relationship extended beyond that shared onstage moment. "If I went backstage, he'd always come out. They'd let me in when they wouldn't let other people in, and we'd have little chats. He always knew I was a fan by the stuff I would ask him."

    Cocker recorded 22 studio albums, the latest being Fire It Up in 2012. One of his most popular works was the double live album Mad Dogs and Englishmen, recorded on tour in 1970. The touring circus featured more than 40 musicians, including Leon Russell, Rita Coolidge and future members of Derek and the Dominos, and resulted in a concert film and Cocker's third gold album.

    Blues soul rock singer Joe Cocker at A&M Records.(Photo: Evening Standard, Getty Images)

    In concert, Cocker relied heavily on cover versions of others' hits, including Feeling Alright, She Came in Through the Bathroom Window, The Letter, Cry Me a River, High Time We Went and Unchain My Heart.

    Cocker said he never tired of revisiting his past: "For a long time, like a lot of artists, I said, 'Oh, God, is this all it means: As you get older, you're just going to keep doing the hits?' But, at the same time, there's something to it. There's a reason they were hits. I enjoy seeing how people reflect from the times."

    Contributing: Haley Blum
